questions.question: Which properties are strictly required to create a minimal working CSS transition?

answer_variants.answer: The property to transition and the duration.

At minimum, `transition-duration` is required. The default property is `all` and default timing is `ease`, but if duration is `0s` (default), nothing happens. So `transition: width 1s` is the minimal useful declaration.
`transition-property` (defaults to all) and `transition-duration` (defaults to 0s). Without duration > 0, the change is instant.
Duration (e.g., 2s) and the Property (e.g., width).
It allows teleportation (instant) to become travel (time). You need to say 'How long' the trip takes.
Property and Duration.
A common mistake is putting the transition on the `:hover` state only. This causes the animation to work on 'Mouse Over' but snap instantly on 'Mouse Out'. It must be on the parent state.
You need to say WHAT you are animating (like color) and HOW LONG it takes (like 2 seconds).
Not all properties are animatable (e.g., `display`, `background-image` often). Check MDN for animatable properties list.
To create a transition effect, you must specify two things: The CSS property you want to add an effect to, and the duration.

questions.question: What is the key functional difference between a CSS Transition and a CSS Animation?

answer_variants.answer: Transitions need a trigger (like hover); Animations run automatically and can loop.

Transitions are implicit (A to B state changes, triggered by user/JS). Animations are explicit (defined by `@keyframes`), can loop (`infinite`), have multiple waypoints (0%, 50%, 100%), and run independently of state changes.
`transition`: 2 states (Start/End). `animation`: N states (Keyframes). `transition`: Reactive. `animation`: Active (or Interactive via specialized properties).
Transition requires a trigger. Animation does not.
Transition is a door closing smoothly when you push it. Animation is a windmill spinning by itself.
Animations can loop and have intermediate steps; transitions are simple A-to-B.
Animations offer granular control over 'fill-mode' (what happens before/after) and 'direction' (alternating), which transitions lack.
Transitions are simple changes (Blue to Red). Animations are complex movies (Blue -> Green -> Red -> Blue, repeat).
Performance-wise, both use the same Compositor thread if optimizing only `opacity` and `transform`.
Transition requires a trigger (hover, focus). Animation works automatically and can have infinite intermediate steps.
The start and end state of the animation cycle.

They represent the time interpolation points. `0%` (alias `from`) is the state at the beginning of the `animation-duration`. `100%` (alias `to`) is the state at the end. You can add any percentage in between (e.g., `50%`) for intermediate steps.
Keyframe selectors. They map the timeline of the animation cycle. Computed style values are interpolated between these keyframes.
Start and End points of the animation.
Like mile markers on a marathon. 0% is the Start Line. 100% is the Finish Line.
Start (`from`) and End (`to`) of the sequence.
If you omit `0%` or `100%`, the browser tries to infer them from the element's current computed styles, which can sometimes cause 'jumping' effects if not careful.
0% is how it looks when it starts. 100% is how it looks when it finishes.
You can list multiple percentages for the same rule: `0%, 100% { transform: scale(1); } 50% { transform: scale(1.2); }` creating a heartbeat effect.
A set of keyframes that indicate the start and end states of the animation's style.

questions.question: What is the correct syntax to define and use a CSS Custom Property (Variable)?

answer_variants.answer: Define: `--color: red;` Use: `color: var(--color);`
Variables are significantly prefixed with double hyphens: `--variable-name`. They are accessed using the function `var(--variable-name)`. They are typically declared in `:root` for global scope.
Declaration: `--<ident>: <value>`. Usage: `var(--<ident> [, <fallback>])`. They obey the cascade and inheritance rules.
Define with `--name`. Use with `var(--name)`.
It is like 'Search and Replace'. You define 'X = Red'. Everywhere you put 'X', the browser sees 'Red'.
`--my-var: 10px;` and `width: var(--my-var);`

Unlike Preprocessor variables (SASS $var) which compile to static values, CSS Variables are live in the DOM. Changing them with JS (`style.setProperty`) instantly updates the page without recompiling.
Name it starting with two dashes. Use it inside the `var()` brackets.
Variables are case-sensitive. `--Color` and `--color` are different properties.
They follow the notation --name and are accessed using the var() function.

questions.question: What is the purpose of defining variables in the `:root` pseudo-class?

answer_variants.answer: It makes the variables available globally (to all elements on the page).

The `:root` selector matches the document's root element (`<html>`). Defining variables there ensures they are globally scoped and inherited by every element in the DOM, making them effective for site-wide theming.

It provides Global Scope. Since CSS variables inherit, setting them at the top of the tree allows access everywhere via `var()`. Defining them on `.card` would limit scope to only `.card` and its children.
To give them global scope.
It's like putting a notice on the Town Hall board (everyone sees it) versus putting it in your kitchen (only your family sees it).
Global availability.
Wait, `:root` has higher specificity than `html`. This is useful when overriding library styles that might use `html { ... }`.
If you put it in root, you can use it anywhere. If you put it in 'div', you can only use it inside divs.
You can redefine a global variable locally. Inside `.dark-mode { --bg: black; }`, the local definition overrides the global one for that subtree.
They are usually defined in the :root pseudo-class for global scope.

questions.question: What does the Child Combinator `>` select?

answer_variants.answer: It selects only direct children (not grandchildren).

`div > p` selects all `

` elements that are **immediate** children of `div`. It does not match paragraphs nested deeper inside other elements within that div.
Selects nodes that are direct descendants of the first element. It does not traverse the DOM tree recursively beyond the first level.
Matches all elements that are children (direct descendants) of a specified element.
Parent > Child. It selects your Son/Daughter, but NOT your Grandson/Granddaughter.
Direct children only.
This is crucial for component isolation. For example, a `.card > .title` style ensures you don't accidentally style a nested card's title if one is inserted inside.
It picks the items directly inside the box, ignoring items inside boxes-inside-the-box.
Contrast with Space (Descendant) combinator which is recursive.
Matches all elements that are children (direct descendants) of a specified element.

questions.question: What does the Adjacent Sibling Combinator `+` do?

answer_variants.answer: It selects the element that is immediately after the first element.

`h1 + p` selects the `

` element that comes *immediately* after the `h1` in the HTML structure. They must share the same parent and be adjacent.
Selects the next sibling element. Examples: `label + input`. Does not affect previous siblings.
Matches an element that is directly after another specific element.
It selects your 'Next Door Neighbor' (only the one to your right).
Selects the immediate next sibling.
Often used for 'Lobotomized Owl' typography (`* + * { margin-top: 1em; }`) or styling labels after checkboxes.
It picks the one thing sitting right next to it.

If there is a text node or comment between them, it still works (conceptual adjacency), but if there is another element (like a `
`), it breaks.
Matches an element that is directly after another specific element.

questions.question: Which selector allows you to target links ending in `.pdf`?

answer_variants.answer: `a[href$='.pdf']`
The 'Ends With' attribute selector: `[attribute$='value']`. So, `a[href$='.pdf']`.
The suffix-match attribute selector `$=`. It matches if the attribute value ends with the specified string.
`a[href$="pdf"]`
The Dollar Sign `$` is often used in Regex to mean 'End of Line'. Same here.
`[src$='.png']` or `[href$='.pdf']`.
Very useful for adding icons to specific link types automatically (`::after { content: icon; }`).
Use the dollar-equals sign to check the end of the link.
Remember it is case sensitive. `.PDF` will not be matched by `.pdf` unless you use the case-insensitive flag `i`: `a[href$='.pdf' i]`.
Select by ending value ($=).
Any element with a class name containing 'col-' anywhere in it.
The `*=` operator is the 'Substring Match' or 'Contains'. It matches if the string 'col-' appears *anywhere* in the class attribute (start, middle, or end).
Substring attribute selector. Matches `class='col-md'`, `class='grid-col'`, and `class='my-col-1'`.
Select by value containing word (substring).
Like Ctrl+F (Find). If the text is there, it matches.
Contains 'col-'.
Dangerous for CSS performance if used excessively on common attributes, as the browser string-matches every element.
It finds any element that has 'col-' inside its class name.
Compared to `|=` (starts with word), `*=` is much looser.
Select by substring (*=).

questions.question: What is the specificity weight of an attribute selector `[type='text']`?

answer_variants.answer: The same as a Class selector (0-1-0).
Attribute selectors have the same specificity as Class selectors and Pseudo-classes. They are weighed as 10 (or 0-1-0). They are heavier than Type selectors (1) but lighter than IDs (100).
Standard Class weight: (0, 1, 0). Combining them sums up: `input[type='text']` = 1 tag + 1 attribute = (0, 1, 1) = 11 points.
Equal to a Class selector.
It acts like a Class.
Same as Class.
This is why `input[type='text']` overrides `input` even if defined earlier. It adds that extra 'Class' weight.
It counts the same as a class name.
This makes them safer than IDs for overrides.
Attribute selectors have the specificity of a class.
